Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: A Predictive Modeling Framework for Exploring Process-Structure-Property Relationships in Organic Solar Cells

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) grant provides funding for the development of a numerical framework to model solvent-based fabrication of thin film organic solar cells. The developed numerical tools will track the evolution of the thin-film morphology (i.e. material distribution) as a function of processing conditions (evaporation rate, spinning speed, annealing time) and configuration (blend-ratio, solvent type and substrate). An adaptive time-stepping strategy along with domain-decomposition and associated parallel computing tools will be used to solve this multiscale, multiphysics problem. A computational tool, based on ideas from graph theory, will be developed to rapidly classify and characterize the predicted morphologies. The numerical predictions will be validated using available microscopy and x-ray diffraction experiments. High throughput simulations will be performed to quantify and understand the effects of solvents, substrate patterning and evaporation conditions on morphology evolution and device performance.

If successful, the results of this research will lead to improvements in the performance of organic photovoltaic devices. The quantitative analysis of morphology evolution during fabrication will accelerate the design process by delivering the ability to directly predict and interpret time-varying three-dimensional snapshots of intermediate morphologies. The high throughput fabrication process-morphology analysis will provide valuable insights toward synthesis and design. The research involves formulating and solving several algorithmic and computing problems, which provide contributions to applied math and computer science in their own right. The proposed work will also educate the next generation of STEM (science, technology, engineering and mathematics) students and the predominantly experimental organic solar cell community about integrating computational thinking with experimental analysis in renewable energy research through education modules, short courses, and open source software.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of the project is to develop mathematical approaches and computational tools to explore process-structure-property relationships in organic electronics. Over the course of the project, we were able to develop virtual manufacturing and characterization tools to understand and rapidly explore how processing conditions affects microstructure, and how microstructure affects device performance in organic electronics (specifically, organic photovoltaic) applications. Taken together, this work presents a promising computational approach towards understanding the process-structure-property relationship governing the behavior of organic electronics. The project outcomes augment the traditional approach in this field, which have been predominately experimental. The integration of such computational and data-driven approaches enables the community to leverage dramatic developments in data sciences, cloud computing and machine learning. The project effectively integrated research with education and workforce development with several PhD graduates who are now in the workforce, as well as training of undergraduate students in computational thinking.

The project consisted of three distinct thrusts. The first thrust focussed on modelling the manufacturing process of organic electronic devices. Solvent-based fabrication is a flexible and affordable approach to manufacture such polymer thin films. The properties of products made from such films are critically affected by the internal organization (morphology) of the films. However, a precise knowledge of morphology evolution leading to the final film structure is critical to unraveling these correlations. In particular, understanding when and where different phases are formed, and how they evolve will provide rational guidelines for more rigorous control of the final morphology. We created a virtual manufacturing framework that predicted the time-history of morphology evolution. We validated this framework with data from experimental collaborators. We subsequently utilized this virtual framework to perform high-throughput parametric sweeps of processing conditions. This data was used to unravel the origin and propagation characteristics of various mechanisms of morphology evolution that has been observed experimentally.

The second thrust focussed on modelling the effect of the morphology of the thin film on the photovoltaic performance of the device. In order to understand the role of morphology on device performance, we developed a scalable computational framework that efficiently interrogates OSCs to investigate relationships between the morphology at the nano-scale with the device performance. We comprehensively modelled the photophysics which is dependent on the spatial distribution of material. The resulting partial differential equations were efficiently solved to predict the current-voltage curve that characterizes the device performance. In addition to the full physics model, we also introduced a suite of morphology descriptors which encode the complex nature of the multi-stage photovoltaic process. These morphology descriptors are easily determined using an approach based on considering a morphology as a graph. We show how these descriptors can be used to interrogate various experimental and synthetic morphologies, allow identification of bottlenecks in the photovoltaic process, and conduct quantitative comparison between morphologies with respect to each sub-process in the photovoltaic phenomena. This framework provides a simple and easy-to-use characterization tool that can be used to unravel the impact of morphology on complex transport phenomena.

The final thrust integrated the tools developed in the first two thrusts with efficient exploration and mapping strategies as well as high-performance and cloud computing to rapidly, efficiently and autonomously explore the process-structure-property space. We utilized concepts from Bayesian sampling and adaptive design-of-experiments to autonomously explore how various processing conditions affect morphology and device performance. The optimization strategy adaptively adjusts the processing parameters to rapidly identify optimal processing configurations, thus reducing the computational effort in process-structure-property explorations. This serves as a modular, parallel 'wrapper' framework that facilitates swapping-in other process simulators and device simulators for general process-structure-property optimization. The methodology developed provides a modular, scalable and extensible approach towards the rational design of tailored microstructures with enhanced functionalities.

The training and workforce development efforts have resulted in several PhD graduates, and training for two post-doctoral associates. Several undergraduate students were trained in computational sciences. We have also worked with several high school students these results at the K-12 level to emphasize to the community the crucial role of computing in science and technology. This work has resulted in high impact papers (in Advanced Energy Materials, Energy and Environmental Sciences) and several conference presentations and invited presentations.
